Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Long-Term Human-Environmental Interaction In a Lowland Tropic Setting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this interdisciplinary study, conducted by researchers at the University of New Mexico (UNM) and Pennsylvania State University (PSU), is to study human-climate-environmental dynamics among the earliest inhabitants of the American tropics. The work is designed to investigate the hypothesis that major behavioral changes in subsistence economies and technology were partially mediated by demographic transitions, climate variability, and anthropogenic environmental change on multiple timescales. The study of human adaptive capacity in the face of rapid environmental change has become more urgent given predictions of future warming and rapid population growth globally. This study is centrally relevant to this societal challenge. It will promote teaching, training, and learning, providing opportunities for collecting original data for graduate and undergraduate student projects at the University of New Mexico, Pennsylvania State University, and other institutions.

The team will conduct a range of archaeological, bioarchaeological, and geochemical analyses on artifacts, skeletal materials (human and non-human), and plant remains from two rockshelter sites in the Maya Mountains of southern Belize with demonstrated occupations ranging between 13,000 and 3,500 years ago. Researchers will also develop a parallel paleoclimate record from nearby cave deposits with incremental geochemical analyses of stalagmites known to span this interval. During this time, humans successfully adapted to tropical habitats, responded to important changes in climate and ecosystem organization, coalesced into the first sedentary communities, and developed agriculture. Precision accelerator mass spectrometry radiocarbon dating of animal and human bone along with stable isotope measurements will be conducted at the PSU Accelerator Mass Spectrometry Facility and UNM Center for Stable isotopes. At PSU, variation in internal bone structure in the lower and upper limbs will be measured using 3D microCT scans to provide insights into human mobility and adaptation to changing lifeways through time. At UNM, and in collaboration with climate science collaborators, the team will develop a high-resolution paleoclimate record from cave stalagmites in the region that will be anchored precisely in time with uranium series dates. The climate backdrop will be used to interpret both cultural and biological change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to frame human behavioral, technological and biological adaptations during the early-to-late Holocene in the Central American neo-tropics and to relate these changes to environmental and climatic shifts. This project was conducted using materials excavated from three rockshelters located in southern Belize, Central America where we have recovered significant numbers of human skeletons, faunal remains, and well-preserved plants and other organic materials spanning the Late Pleistocene to the present.  We hypothesized that early human colonists arriving in region (pre-12,500 BP) would have encountered and successfully adapted to a vastly different landscape and climate regime than that of today, based on a significant body of archaeological and paleoclimate and palaeoecological research elsewhere in the region.

We conducted osteological analysis of 76 ancient skeleton dating between 9,600-1,000 BP including basic metrics related age, sex, and stature.  These individuals range from a perinate to older adult (>60).  We have conducted additional analysis to document pathologies and other life-history markers from bone and teeth. These analyses we coupled with detailed studies of the mortuary contexts and material culture recovered from the same contexts, specifically lithic materials.  With our collaborators we have directly dated 52 individual skeletons using purified bone collagen and dental enamel. We produced over 200 radiocarbon dates from the two primary rockshelters, demonstrating that they were used persistently throughout the Holocene. We recovered isotopes of carbon and nitrogen from bone and teeth to assess diet, and we recovered strontium to assess mobility.  With our collaborators we have generated ancient DNA from 31 individuals.

Humans using the three rockshelter sites hunted larger animals and used bifacial tools during the Terminal Pleistocene and Early Holocene but abandoned bifacial technologies during the Middle Holocene at the same time that plant management was being an important subsistence strategy in the neotropics. This is consistent with sites across the neotropics. These early humans are linked to some of the founding human lineages in the New World. At the end of the Middle Holocene there is evidence of interaction and gene flow from Isthmian region of lower Central America and northern Colombia. This occurs just before we begin to see evidence of limited maize consumption at ~4,700 BP.  By 4,000 BP all individuals in our skeletal population are maize consumers with the staple grain contributing ~70 percent to the diet.

Humans using the three rockshelter sites hunted larger animals and used bifacial tools during the terminal Pleistocene and Early Holocene but abandoned bifacial technologies during the Middle Holocene at the same time that plant management was being an important subsistence strategy in the neotropics and people were relying more on smaller animals as sources of protein. This is consistent with sites across the neotropics. These early humans are linked to some of the founding human lineages in the New World. At the end of the Middle Holocene there is evidence of interaction and gene flow from Isthmian region of lower Central America and northern Colombia. This occurs just before we begin to see evidence of limited maize consumption at ~4,700 BP.  By 4,000 BP all individuals in our skeletal population are maize consumers with the staple grain contributing ~70 percent to the diet.  

Our data show that in the neotropical Maya Lowlands during the Early and Middle Holocene people were more closely linked to neighboring populations to the south, sharing technologies and exploiting similar resources available in broadleaf rainforests.  Consistent with studies in South America we see consumption of maize as a grain occurring earlier than previously thought. Our data indicate that maize was a stable grain at least 700 years prior to the first sedentary communities known in the region.

With a robust assemblage of early human skeletons to work with and the support of leaders of descendent communities we are able to make significant contributions to the archaeological sciences in areas of early technologies, subsistence, mobility, ancestry, adaptations to environmental change and mortuary practices.  We have adopted a collaborative research model involving local NGO collaborators and indigenous descendent communities. The impacts are that our research with our local conservation partners allows us to rely on them for logistical and permit related support. Local presentation and dissemination of our project results help our partners to codify the importance of management of ancient sites and cultural resources in the larger context of environmental conservation and protection.  Our work with local communities promotes ethical research and provides valuable information on the cultural past in a region where indigenous voices have been largely muted.
